repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Attempt for: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/8200

Does not currently solve the issue, wip.

This is an attempt to handle `CTRL-C` gracefully when a quickfix command is to be cancelled. The command is cancelled but the delays set by the quickfix remains.

comment_data.body: what happens if you remove this? I think we would prefer not to modify 'writedelay' on ctrl-c, that would be a different kind of annoying ...
You then have to `Ctrl-C` multiple times, e.g. after `C-w s`,which I think is good, and similar to how Vim behaves.
Not sure about the other conditions besides `got_int` here: wouldn't that skip the delay in case of `echoerr` etc, which shouldn't be the case?

what if a timer or something causes frequent redraws? At least a second `Ctrl-C` in a short while should reset `p_wd` if not the first. One can have keybindings that quickly sets `'wd'` to a sensible positive and negative value respectively.
Should likely cause a message then?

Too verbose. Instead:

    <C-C><C-C> resets writedelay to 0.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6926,4 +6926,8 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	When negative, all redrawn characters cause a delay, even if the
 	character already was displayed by the UI.  For debugging purposes.
 
+	Once writedelay is set to some postitive or negative integer, it
+	can be reset to 0 by triggering two interrupts (Hitting <C-C> two
+	times)

comment_data.body:
ui_cursor_goto seems to hide the effects (if any) of  HL_STANDOUT/`ui_putc('X')`. The cursor placement helps  visually, so I don't think HL_STANDOUT/`ui_putc('X')` is needed.

Also, I tested this locally, and moved it back to `ui_puts()` and it seems to work fine there, so it should stay there.

The only changes needed are the checks for `got_int` . Let's move forward with that.
Or `Using CTRL-C twice (during one main loop iteration) will reset it.`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6926,4 +6926,8 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	When negative, all redrawn characters cause a delay, even if the
 	character already was displayed by the UI.  For debugging purposes.
 
+	Once writedelay is set to some postitive or negative integer, it
+	can be reset to 0 by triggering two interrupts (Hitting <C-C> two
+	times)

comment_data.body:
> ui_cursor_goto seems to hide the effects (if any) of HL_STANDOUT/ui_putc('X')

Depends on the cursor shape (IIRC).
But I agree that it is not necessary really, and using a block cursor would be the better improvement (but is not necessary).

comment_regular_data.body:
how is quickfix related to #8200 ? I would think a change is needed in the area of `ui_puts` or `char_needs_redraw`.  I found those cases using `git grep` for `p_wd` (which is the 'writedelay' option):

    git grep p_wd

@justinmk oh! I thought It was the `ex_redraw` command that was causing the issue. Thanks for pointing out! :)

The latest commit fixes the issue. if it's alright then I'll squash it.

Not setting `&wd = 0` makes it harder to abort, since `Ctrl-c` then triggers a redraw of the statusline / display of the "Type  :quit<Enter>  to exit Nvim" message (which needs to be canceled itself), and then continues with the previous redrawing (e.g. the syntax highlighting for the startify buffer).

@blueyed The diff you posted works great. the `redraw!` event gets cancelled on the 1st interrupt and wd set to 0 on the second.
Also just this, `if (!got_int) {` works.

Also it would be nice to have a block cursor always when redrawing, but it does not seem to be trivial.
Would likely need to call `ui_call_mode_change`?

> What do you think about a message when &wd is reset? 

Let's just document it. 'writedelay' is only for developers anyways.
I'll write a test for it.

@geekodour 
What's the state of this?  Would be great to get this finished - and I'd be happy to help.
Needs rebase. `ui_puts` was changed into `ui_line`, though the same logic should apply.
@blueyed @bfredl I am very rusty on the nvim codebase. I'll rebase this to resolve the conflicts today. I think it will be resolved faster if someone takes over the PR after that. :/

labels.description: community: Google Summer of Code project
labels.name: gsoc

title: Canceling writedelay on double CTRL-C
